sen.j: 十二神社（じゅうにじんじゃ）は、奈良県天理市にある神社である。
sen.e: Juni-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Tenri City, Nara Prefecture.
Juni-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Tenri City, Nara Prefecture.
Juni-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Tenri City, Nara Prefecture.

sen.j: 延喜式神名帳「大和国山辺郡 夜都伎神社」の論社である（他の論社は同市乙木町の夜都岐神社と田井庄町の八剣神社 (天理市)）。
sen.e: The shrine is a Ronja (shrines considered to be descendants of a shikinai-sha) of a shrine registered in Engishiki Jimmyocho (a register of shrines in Japan), 'Yatsugi-jinja Shrine in Yamabe County, Yamato Province' (Yatsugi-jinja Shrine in Otogi-cho, Tenri City and Yatsurugi-jinja Shrine in Tainosho-cho, Tenri City are other Ronja).

The shrine is a ronja (shrine considered to be predecessor of a shikinaisha) of a shrine registered in the Engishiki Jinmyocho (a register of shrines in Japan), 'Yatsugi-jinja Shrine in Yamabe County, Yamato Province' (other ronja are Yatsugi-jinja Shrine in Otogi-cho, Tenri City and Yatsurugi-jinja Shrine in Tainosho-cho, Tenri City).

The shrine is a ronja (shrine considered to be predecessor of a shikinaisha) of a shrine registered in the Engishiki Jinmyocho (a register of shrines in Japan), 'Yatsugi-jinja Shrine in Yamabe County, Yamato Province' (other ronja are Yatsugi-jinja Shrine in Otogi-cho, Tenri City and Yatsurugi-jinja Shrine in Tainosho-cho, Tenri City).

sen.j: 祭神
sen.e: Enshrined deities
Enshrined deities
Enshrined deities

sen.j: 祭神は以下に示す日本書紀本文に記される神世七代11柱の神および天照大神で、
sen.e: Juni-jinja Shrine enshrines the under-mentioned 12 deities described in Nihon-shoki (the oldest chronicles of Japan): 11 deities of Kaminoyonanayo (seven generations of the deities' world, The Primordial Seven) and Amaterasu-omikami.

Juni-jinja Shrine enshrines the following 11 Kaminoyonanayo (seven generations of the deities' world, The Primordial Seven) deities described in Nihon-shoki (the oldest chronicles of Japan) and Amaterasu-omikami.
sen.cmt: Rewritten to reflect the source text and make sense.
sen.e: Juni-jinja Shrine enshrines the following 11 Kaminoyonanayo (seven generations of the deities' world, The Primordial Seven) deities described in Nihon-shoki (the oldest chronicles of Japan) and Amaterasu-omikami.

sen.j: 「十二神社」の社名はそれに由来するものである。
sen.e: As the figure "12" is read as "Juni" in Japanese, enshrining 12 deities is the origin of the shrine's name of 'Juni-jinja Shrine.'
As the number '12' is read 'juni' in Japanese, the name 'Juni-jinja Shrine' derives from the fact that the shrine enshrines twelve deities.
As the number '12' is read 'juni' in Japanese, the name 'Juni-jinja Shrine' derives from the fact that the shrine enshrines twelve deities.

sen.j: 江戸時代は十二社大明神と称していた。
sen.e: In the Edo period, this shrine was referred to as "Juni-sha Daimyojin Shrine."
In the Edo period, this shrine was referred to as "Juni-sha Daimyojin Shrine."
In the Edo period, this shrine was referred to as "Juni-sha Daimyojin Shrine."

sen.j: ウヒヂニ・スヒヂニ

Uhijini-no-kami ・Suhijini-no-kami

sen.j: 歴史
sen.e: History
History
History

sen.j: 奈良盆地でも珍しい、標高100ｍ以上の高地に位置する環濠集落である、竹之内の集落の東北奥に位置する。
sen.e: The shrine is in the remotest northeastern part of Takenouchi village, an uncommon moat settlement in the Nara Basin, which is located in the highland at an altitude of 100m or more.
The shrine is in the remotest northeastern part of Takenouchi village, an uncommon moat settlement in the Nara Basin, which is located in the highlands at an altitude of 100m or more.
The shrine is in the remotest northeastern part of Takenouchi village, an uncommon moat settlement in the Nara Basin, which is located in the highlands at an altitude of 100m or more.

sen.j: また、竹之内集落の濠は、現在も集落の西側に残っている。
sen.e: Meanwhile, the moat of Takenouchi village has still remained in the west of the village.
Meanwhile, the moat of Takenouchi village has still remained in the west of the village.
Meanwhile, the moat of Takenouchi village has still remained in the west of the village.

sen.j: 伝承によれば、江戸時代、乙木村の産土神である夜都岐神社の社地と、現在の十二神社の社地である竹之内村の三間塚池（さぎづかいけ）を交換したという。
sen.e: According to a tradition, Juni-jinja Shrine's current land of Sagizuka-ike Pond in Takenouchi village, was exchanged with that of Yatsugi-jinja Shrine which enshrines the ubusunagami (guardian deity of one's birthplace) of Otogi village during the Edo period.

According to a tradition, Juni-jinja Shrine's current land of Sagizuka-ike Pond in Takenouchi village, was exchanged with that of Yatsugi-jinja Shrine which enshrines the ubusunagami (guardian deity of one's birthplace) of Otogi village during the Edo period.

According to a tradition, Juni-jinja Shrine's current land of Sagizuka-ike Pond in Takenouchi village, was exchanged with that of Yatsugi-jinja Shrine which enshrines the ubusunagami (guardian deity of one's birthplace) of Otogi village during the Edo period.

sen.j: 竹之内村の本来の産土神は白山神社（白山権現社）であったが、明治時代に当社に神社合祀された。
sen.e: Takenouchi village had originally enshrined Hakusan-jinja Shrine (Hakusan Gongen-sha Shrine) as Ubusunagami that was merged with Juni-jinja Shrine in the Meiji period.
Takenouchi village had originally enshrined Hakusan-jinja Shrine (Hakusan Gongen-sha Shrine) as Ubusunagami that was merged with Juni-jinja Shrine in the Meiji period.
Takenouchi village had originally enshrined Hakusan-jinja Shrine (Hakusan Gongen-sha Shrine) as Ubusunagami that was merged with Juni-jinja Shrine in the Meiji period.

sen.j: 境内
sen.e: Precincts
Precinct
Precinct

sen.j: 拝殿の前には神石があり、参拝前に「ワハッハ」と声を出して笑い三回周囲を廻る風習がある。
sen.e: It is the custom of Juni-jinja Shrine to go round a Kamiishi (a holy stone) enshrined in front of Haiden (a hall of worship) three times, while laughing aloud with a word 'Wahha ha.'
there is a holy stone in front of the haiden (worship hall) and it is the custom at Juni-jinja Shrine to circle it three times while laughing "waha ha."
there is a holy stone in front of the haiden (worship hall) and it is the custom at Juni-jinja Shrine to circle it three times while laughing "waha ha" before offering prayers.

sen.j: 境内社に七柱神社・多賀神社がある。
sen.e: Nanahashira-jinja Shrine and Taga-jinja Shrine are Keidai-sha Shrine (shrines in precincts).
Nanahashira-jinja Shrine and Taga-jinja Shrine are keidaisha (auxiliary shrines within the precinct of the main shrine).
Nanahashira-jinja Shrine and Taga-jinja Shrine are keidaisha (auxiliary shrines within the precinct of the main shrine).

sen.j: 当社の北側には地元の人が「火の谷」と呼ぶ地域がある。
sen.e: A region in the north of the shrine is called 'Hi-no-tani' (literally meaning, "a fire valley") by the locals.
An area to the north of the shrine is called 'Hi-no-tani' (lit. fire valley) by locals.
An area to the north of the shrine is called 'Hi-no-tani' (lit. fire valley) by locals.

sen.j: 「夜都岐」は「八剣」が変化したものとされる。
sen.e: The shrine's name of 'Yatsugi-jinja Shrine' comes from that of 'Yatsurugi-jinja Shrine.'
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: The shrine's name of 'Yatsugi-jinja Shrine' comes from that of 'Yatsurugi-jinja Shrine.'
The shrine's name of 'Yatsugi-jinja Shrine' comes from that of 'Yatsurugi-jinja Shrine.'

sen.j: 各地の八剣神社の創建譚に「日の谷」の地名がよく登場することから関連があるものとみられる。
sen.e: The above-mentioned 'Hi-no-tani' is assumably relevant to Yatsurugi-jinja Shrine, because a place name of 'Hi-no-tani' (same pronunciation, but literally meaning "a sun valley") often appears in the story explaining the shrine's foundation that has come down in each Yatsurugi-jinja Shrine nationwide.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: The above-mentioned 'Hi-no-tani' is presumably relevant to Yatsurugi-jinja Shrine, because the place name 'Hi-no-tani' (same pronunciation, but literally meaning 'sun valley') often appears in the story explaining the shrine's founding of Yatsurugi-jinja Shrines nationwide.

The above-mentioned 'Hi-no-tani' is presumably relevant to Yatsurugi-jinja Shrine, because the place name 'Hi-no-tani' (same pronunciation, but literally meaning 'sun valley') often appears in the story explaining the shrine's founding of Yatsurugi-jinja Shrines nationwide.
